A landmark Supreme Court decision in 2022 made it easier for Americans to carry handguns in public and set a precedent requiring gun prohibitions to have historical roots.
Hunter Biden was convicted in 2024 under the same federal law, and later pardoned by President Joe Biden.

keyTakeAways: The Supreme Court agreed to review a federal law that bars certain drug users from possessing firearms, specifically focusing on habitual marijuana users.

The case centers on Ali Danial Hemani, a dual citizen of the U.S. and Pakistan, who was charged in 2023 after marijuana and cocaine were found at his home, with prosecutors citing his habitual drug use.
A federal district court initially dismissed the charge, citing a 2022 Supreme Court precedent that requires gun prohibitions to have historical roots and be tied to past laws.
The 5th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals upheld the precedent, ruling that the law cannot target habitual drug users, only those under the influence at the time of arrest.
The Trump administration appealed, arguing that habitual drug users with guns pose a danger to law enforcement and society, particularly while impaired.

The DOJ alleged in its appeal that Hemani was involved in fraud linked to Iranian Revolutionary Guard Corps affiliates and attended a celebration for Qasem Soleimani, killed in a 2020 U.S. drone strike.

Hemani's legal team challenged the historical basis of the law, noting that nearly half of U.S. states have legalized recreational marijuana and that there is significant overlap between legal marijuana users and gun ownership.
Hunter Biden, son of President Joe Biden, was convicted in 2024 under the same law and later pardoned by President Biden.
This case is part of a broader legal debate about the scope of the Second Amendment and whether modern drug use laws can withstand constitutional scrutiny.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The Supreme Court has agreed to review a federal law that bans certain drug users from possessing firearms, specifically targeting habitual marijuana users. The case centers on Ali Danial Hemani, a U.S.-Pakistan dual citizen, who was indicted in 2023 after marijuana and cocaine were found at his home. A lower court dismissed the charge, citing a 2022 Supreme Court precedent that requires gun prohibitions to have historical roots and be tied to past laws. The 5th Circuit Court of Appeals upheld that precedent, ruling that such laws cannot target habitual drug users. The Trump administration appealed, arguing that such users pose a danger to law enforcement and society, especially while impaired. The DOJ also alleged connections between Hemani and Iran, including fraud with Iranian Revolutionary Guard Corps affiliates and participation in a celebration of Qasem Soleimani’s life. Hemani’s legal team challenged the historical basis of the law, noting widespread state-level legalization of marijuana. Notably, Hunter Biden, the son of President Joe Biden, was previously convicted under the same law and later pardoned. The Supreme Court is expected to hear arguments in the Hemani case next year and issue a decision by the end of June 2026, reigniting debate on the balance between Second Amendment rights and public safety in drug-related gun restrictions.
title: Justices Agree to Review Federal Law Banning Drug Users from Possessing Guns
